qas.question: What pump can capture gases in a solid or absorbed state?
Entrapment pumps often work without seals, moving parts and what else?
What pump has a higher quality vacuum than a positive displacement pump?
What can positive displacement pumps achieve more than entrapment pumps?

plausible_answers.text: gases in a solid or absorbed state

qas.question: What can momentum transfer pumps capture?
Dynamic pumps often work without moving parts, seals and what?
What are entrapment pumps usually considered above all of the others?
What other pump do entrapment pumps have similarities to?

context: The above explanation is merely a simple introduction to vacuum pumping, and is not representative of the entire range of pumps in use. Many variations of the positive displacement pump have been developed, and many other pump designs rely on fundamentally different principles. <a2_0>Momentum transfer pumps<a2_0/>, which bear some similarities to <b7_0>dynamic pumps<b7_0/> used at higher pressures, can achieve <b3_0>much higher quality vacuums<b3_0/> than positive displacement pumps. <a0_0>Entrapment pumps<a0_0/> can capture <b4_0>gases in a solid or absorbed state<b4_0/>, often with no moving parts, no seals and <a1_0>no <b5_0>vibration<b5_0/>.<a1_0/> None of these pumps are <b6_0>universal<b6_0/>; each type has important performance limitations. They all share a difficulty in pumping low molecular weight gases, especially hydrogen, helium, and neon.
